review_title: Fairfield University: A solid place with strong ideals
pros: As a university, it seems pretty well managed and well financed, with a sound clientele (student body) and a clear sense of its mission, including balancing the money-making departments of the university with traditional departments more closely aligned with higher (non-lucrative) ideals.
cons:
Leadership/ management quality can vary significantly depending if you are dealing with the dept. chair (direct supervisor), and how competent he/ she is in interpersonal skills, or assistant/ associate deans.  My dept. chair was excellent, but was in that position for only a few years. The position rotates, and I'm not confident that other members of the dept. would be equally capable in taking it on.  Second, there was an assoc. dean on staff who was markedly not competent -- this person was later edged out, I think. But a general problem in academia is too much job security -- people like the assoc. dean are hard to get rid of.  

In general, however, I found management up the ranks, to be competent and fair.  Some of my colleagues were too complacent, I thought, but this is probably par for the course.

pros: The benefit of getting a college education at no cost.  The professors are wonderful, dedicated people who will do anything to enhance the learning process.
cons:
The pay scale is very low.  It is almos next to impossible to get promotions.  The trend seems to be to hired outside the university first so that lower rates of pay can be offered.  The more qualified and experience workers are overlooked.
The majority of the managers are promoted without training as supervisors, so there are alot of inexperienced managers that do not know how to deal with work place situations.  The human resource office here is a joke.  They do not support the employee one bit - it is almost as if they do not want to bother.  Whatever the supervisor says goes - which is dangerous, especially for the morale of the department

review_title: Too many chiefs and not enough workers
pros: The professors and staff are some of the most dedicated people I have ever met and have had the privilege to know.
cons: There are just too many chiefs - people are getting promotions and "huge" salary increases of close to 20% while the worker bees are ignored and more worked is given to us to do because the chiefs are too important now.

review_title: Great place to work, but concerns about senior management
pros:
- Great benefits including 401K contribution plan, rec plex membership, discounts on events at Quick Center
- Sense of community
cons:
- Members of senior management do not seem vested in University
- Recent staff layoffs and seemingly lack of appreciation by senior management have played a serious toll on morale causing there to be a revolving door in some divisions.
- Some in senior management are degrading to staff; HR seems uninterested.

pros: The benefits are great as is the work life balance.  Generous time off for Christmas and half day Fridays during summer.  Cheap gym membership.
cons: Not enough room for growth and low pay with no bonus.  Top management has been plucked from the corporate world and work environment starting to reflect that.

pros: Great people to work with in all aspects. Very friendly management who are understanding and want you to move on to succeed at everything you do.
cons: poorly run administration at times due to lack of communication. Also, some NCAA restrictions and budget defecits prohibit fairfield to be what it truly can be.

pros: Such a great family at Fairfield University.  I started my career at the university and really grew a lot over my time there.  I would recommend working here to anyone
cons: I really saw few negatives.  The pay is obviously lower than the private sector but theres so many built in holidays and half day fridays are amazing

pros: I have been a student here at the graduate school of  Business and it has been wonderful studying here. I have learnt so much that am ready to apply inn the real world out there.
cons: The only downside is that am finishing school but have not been able to get a job yet.

pros: Being a tour guide allows me to show potential students around campus and sell the university to them. It has been a great experience with minimal hours, but very fulfilling.
cons: There are very few, if any cons with this position. It is once a week, or more if you would like to do so. However, it is unpaid unless you do more than 1 tour a week.

review_title: There are lots of good people, but be careful with political people...
pros: There are several really dedicated faculty who love students and will do anything for them.
cons: There are some distorted people who care more about their personal agenda than students or the school.

pros:
job security
great vacation benefits
great retirement benefits; university matches your payments into your retirement fund
great co-workers; people care about others
cons:
job security has become issue
no opportunity for career advancement; only opportunity to get more responsibilities
no ability to be paid what your worth

pros: The people are wonderful, the campus is beautiful, the work is interesting and engaging.  The benefits are very good, especially paid time off and pension.
cons: The place is changing.  Fairfield used to display it's Jesuit values and ideals in every area.  Now it seems to be turning into a corporate like work environment.

review_title: Great coworkers, deserve to be paid fairly

cons: Adjunct faculty aren't compensated all that fairly. Sometimes there are office politics, which can detract from getting work done.
